name: Lean FIRE
description: Lean FIRE means achieving financial independence on a minimal budget ‚Äî typically under $40,000 per year. Lean FIREs prioritize freedom over luxury, often living in low cost-of-living areas, embracing minimalism, and optimizing every dollar. The lower FIRE number makes it achievable much faster.
pros: Smallest FIRE number ‚Äî easiest to achieve
Can be achieved in 10-15 years on average income
cons: May need to return to work in market downturns
Healthcare costs can strain a lean budget
bestFor: Single individuals, minimalists, digital nomads, those willing to geo-arbitrage or live in low cost-of-living areas

name: Barista FIRE
description: Barista FIRE (named after Starbucks barista health benefits) means building a portfolio large enough to cover most expenses, then supplementing with enjoyable part-time or flexible work. You're not fully retired ‚Äî but you've escaped the full-time grind and work on your terms.
pros: Smaller portfolio needed than full FIRE
Psychological ease of transition from work
cons: Part-time income may not always be available
bestFor: People who want to leave stressful careers but still enjoy some work, those who need healthcare coverage, early FIREs who want a buffer

name: Regular FIRE
tagline: The classic path to financial independence
description: Traditional FIRE ‚Äî full financial independence on $60,000-$100,000 per year. You accumulate enough to never need to work again, living comfortably on 4% annual withdrawals. This is what most people mean when they say FIRE.
cons: Takes longer to achieve than Lean FIRE
bestFor: Couples, families, those in high cost-of-living areas, people who want a comfortable retirement without extreme frugality

name: Fat FIRE
description: Fat FIRE means retiring on $100,000+ per year ‚Äî living lavishly while never working again. Fat FIREs build portfolios of $2.5M-$10M+ and enjoy travel, dining, luxury experiences, and financial security. It requires high income and high savings rates, but offers the most comfortable retirement.
pros: Large buffer for healthcare, dependents, luxury
Ability to gift, give, and leave legacy
Complete freedom without any lifestyle constraints
cons: Typically requires high income to achieve
May take 20-30 years even with high savings rate
Identity challenges if career was central to life
bestFor: High earners, those with dependents, people with expensive hobbies or health conditions, those who want maximum security and comfort

name: Coast FIRE
tagline: Save aggressively now, coast to retirement
description: Coast FIRE means saving enough early in your career that ‚Äî without any further contributions ‚Äî your investments will grow to your FIRE number by traditional retirement age. Once you've hit your Coast number, you only need to earn enough to cover current expenses.
pros: Can downshift to lower-paying but fulfilling work
Compound growth does the heavy lifting
Intermediate goal makes FIRE more achievable
Reduces financial stress while still working
cons: Still working until traditional retirement age
Requires discipline to not touch investments
Inflation risk over long coast period
Healthcare still needs to be funded
May feel like a compromise vs. full early retirement
bestFor: People who want to reduce financial stress without fully stopping work, career changers, parents, those who started saving early and want to pivot
